facts.text: Appellant C. I. Emden was Loco Foreman at Alambagh Loco Shed.
Shukla secured contract at Alambagh Loco Shed for removal of cinders from ash pits and loading coal in June 1952.
Appellant demanded Rs. 400 per month from Shukla as bribe to allow peaceful execution of contract without harassment, mentioning previous contractor Ram Ratan paid monthly.
Shukla refused demand, leading to hostile acts by appellant.
On January 3, 1953, appellant again demanded monthly bribe; Shukla requested reduction due to smaller contract amount; appellant agreed to Rs. 375.
Shukla lacked money, asked for time; agreed to pay on January 8, 1953.
Shukla informed Deputy Superintendent of Police, Corruption Branch; statement recorded before magistrate; trap decided.
On January 8, 1953, raiding party (Shukla, magistrate, DSP, others) went to Loco Yard; Shukla and Sada Shiv entered; others at gate.
Shukla met appellant inside, informed money brought; appellant went out to yard, to secluded place around 3 p.m.; asked for money; Shukla gave bundle of marked currency notes Rs. 375.
Shukla gave signal; raiding party arrived; magistrate identified, asked appellant to produce money; appellant took out notes from pocket and handed to magistrate.
Appellant admitted receiving Rs. 375 from Shukla but claimed it was loan at his request for children's clothing expenses; alleged requested Kishan Chand for Rs. 500 loan, but Shukla offered Rs. 375.

Special Judge tried case in Criminal Case No. 2/3/32/45 of 1953-55; believed Shukla's evidence corroborated; defence improbable; raised presumption u/s 4 Act, not rebutted; convicted u/s 161 IPC (1 year RI + Rs.500 fine) and s.5(2) Act (2 years RI), concurrent.

Allahabad High Court (Lucknow Bench) in Criminal Appeal No. 515 of 1955: raised presumption u/s 4, not rebutted; confirmed conviction; maintained s.161 sentence, reduced s.5(2) to 1 year RI, concurrent.
Appellant had bank balance of Rs. 1,600; salary Rs. 600/month; children to school in March, no immediate clothing need; planned daughter's marriage.
Unlikely Shukla would lend to appellant given hostile relations.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.4(1) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 is unconstitutional as violating Art. 14 of Constitution.
When does presumption under s.4(1) arise: on mere proof of acceptance of gratification other than legal remuneration, or requires proof that it was by way of bribe?
What is the standard of proof for accused to rebut presumption under s.4(1): beyond reasonable doubt or mere reasonable probability?

petitioner_arguments.text: S.4(1) violates Art.14 as unreasonable classification without rational relation to object.
Presumption under s.4(1) arises only if prosecution proves money accepted as bribe, not mere receipt; 'gratification' implies bribe.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(1) Prevention of Corruption Act; compared to English Act s.2

petitioner_arguments.text: To rebut presumption, accused need only provide reasonably probable explanation, not proof beyond reasonable doubt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(1) Prevention of Corruption Act; Evidence Act; precedents like Otto George Gfeller, Rex v. Carr Briant

petitioner_arguments.text: Explanation of loan for children's clothing is reasonably probable; supported by witnesses Kishan Chand, Ram Ratan.

respondent_arguments.text: S.4(1) based on reasonable classification of public servants accused of bribery, rational nexus to eradicate corruption.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 14; Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia case

respondent_arguments.text: 'Gratification' means literal satisfaction, includes money other than legal remuneration; presumption arises on proof of receipt alone.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(1), s.161 IPC; s.161 para 3; State v. Pundlik Bhikaji Ahire, Promod Chander Shekhar v. Rex

respondent_arguments.text: Rebuttal requires proof as per Evidence Act s.3,4: court believes or considers probable for prudent man.

court_reasoning.text: S.4(1) constitutional: reasonable classification of public servants for bribery charges, intelligible differentia with rational relation to object of eradicating corruption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Experience shows bribery hard to prove; presumption aids clean administration.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption arises on proof accused accepted gratification (money) other than legal remuneration; no need to prove as bribe beforehand; 'gratification' not confined to pecuniary or bribe intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consistent with 'valuable thing' clause; otherwise presumption superfluous.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's receipt of Rs.375 admitted, not legal remuneration; presumption raised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court justified in raising presumption.

court_reasoning.text: Assume for appellant lighter burden (reasonable probability suffices to rebut); but explanation improbable: bank balance Rs.1600, salary Rs.600, no urgent clothing need, hostile relations with Shukla, interested witnesses.
High Court disbelieved defence evidence; no reliance on inadmissible statement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conclusion based on oral evidence and probabilities.

holdings.text: S.4(1) Prevention of Corruption Act constitutional, does not violate Art.14.
Presumption under s.4(1) mandatory when proved accused accepted gratification other than legal remuneration.
Appellant's defence fails to rebut presumption; conviction under s.161 IPC and s.5(2) Act upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 permits reasonable classification with rational nexus.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. S. Krishna v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar statutory presumption upheld against Art.14 challenge.
Supported need to prove bribe for presumption (not accepted).
Supported need to prove bribe for presumption (not accepted).

precedents_cited.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Accused explanation if breaks down, may convict; reasonable truth test.
Burden on accused less than prosecution; probability suffices.
Burden on accused less than beyond reasonable doubt.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of bribery by public servant; presumption linked to these.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption on acceptance of gratification; conviction under s.5(2).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality before law; challenge to s.4(1) rejected.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; conviction and sentences under s.161 IPC (1 year RI + Rs.500 fine) and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act (1 year RI), concurrent, confirmed by High Court upheld.

key_quotes.text: Art. 14 does not forbid reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia and that the said differentia have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding constitutionality of s.4(1).

key_quotes.text: Where money is shown to have been paid to, and accepted by, such public servant and that the said money does not constitute his legal remuneration, the presumption has to be raised.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Construction of when presumption under s.4(1) arises.

key_quotes.text: The explanation given by the accused was improbable and palpably unreasonable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejection of defence, failure to rebut presumption.
